title: How far-right ideas are becoming mainstream in French media
summary: Far-right politicians, journalists, and activists are delighted that their 'cultural combat' has moved from relatively confidential publications to highly-watched television channels.

title: 'What is more important? Art or the right to sustainable food?' said activists, splashing soup on Mona Lisa casing
summary: The activist group behind the protest, the latest in a string of similar attacks against artworks, demanded 'the social security of sustainable food.' A timely request, as French farmers protest across the country to demand better pay and fewer regulations.

title: Measles is making a worrying comeback in the UK
summary: After an acceleration in the rate of measles infections since the start of the year, the British national health system has launched a vast emergency awareness campaign aimed at 4 million parents.

title: French farmer unions vow to put Paris under 'indefinite siege' in income, tax and regulation protests
summary: Farmers from the Lot-et-Garonne, one of the hotspots of the protest movement in southern France, had already announced their intention to 'go to Paris' on Monday.

title: Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger leave ECOWAS regional bloc
summary: The three countries' putchist regimes announced their quitting the West African bloc, citing it as 'a threat to member states and peoples,' in a new chapter of tensions fueled by Russian meddling and mistrust of France.

title: European Handball Championship 2024: France defeats Denmark in extra-time final thriller
summary: Bleu pivot Ludovic Fabregas starred as the Olympic champions edged out world champions Denmark 33-31 in Cologne on Sunday, January 28. Earlier, Sweden defeated hosts Germany to take third place.

title: AFCON 2024: Congo knocks Egypt out of competition on penalties
summary: DR Congo dumped out seven-time Africa Cup of Nations winners Egypt after an epic penalty shootout in the round-of-16 match. The 'Red Devils' will next face Guinea.

title: Armenia suggests non-aggression pact be signed with Azerbaijan
summary: Normalization talks between the two countries (mediated by EU chief Charles Michel) had been on hold since October 2023, as traditional regional power broker Russia, bogged down with its dragging Ukraine offensive, has seen its influence wane in the Caucasus.

title: Biden says US 'shall respond' after Iran-backed drone strike kills 3 US troops in Jordan
summary: Three US Army soldiers were killed and 34 service members were injured in a drone attack on a small US outpost in Jordan, on the night of January 27. The strike marks the first time US troops have been killed by enemy fire in the Middle East since the beginning of the war against Hamas.

title: In South Korea, the world's lowest fertility rate sinks lower and lower
summary: In his column, researcher Sébastien Lechevalier reports on how the causes of declining fertility among Korean women vary from generation to generation.

title: Former prime minister Stubb wins first round of Finland's presidential vote
summary: The first-round election result will be officially confirmed on Tuesday, January 30. The result will push the race into a runoff on February 11 between Alexander Stubb and former foreign minister Pekka Haavisto.

title: Istanbul Catholic church attacked by armed assailants
summary: The attack, which was committed by two masked men during Sunday mass, killed one man and, according to local authorities, left no wounded. This has prompted officials to view it as a targeted attack on the victim, rather than against the Catholic church.

title: Australian Open: Sinner clinches comeback win over Medvedev in men's final
summary: Italian newcomer Jannik Sinner started the intense final two sets down against Russian third seed Daniil Medvedev, but then powered back over three sets to win his first-ever Grand Slam title.

title: The United States approves the sale of F-16 fighter jets to Turkey after a year of NATO tensions
summary: When Turkey's opposition to Sweden's NATO membership was lifted on January 23, it helped to convince holdouts in the US Senate who had been reluctant to sign an agreement with this unpredictable ally.

title: Giorgia Meloni's African ambition
summary: The Italian prime minister is organizing an Italy-Africa summit in Rome, on January 28 and 29. She will on that occasion to present her 'plan for Africa' to cement Italy's role on the continent.

title: Mouthpieces close to the Kremlin announce the arrival of Russian 'military specialists' in Burkina Faso
summary: Ibrahim Traoré's junta continues its rapprochement with the Putin regime. Sources claim that several hundred Russian troops have being deployed in the country.

title: Saudi Arabia to open first government-run liquor store
summary: Sales will be limited to non-Muslim diplomats in Riyadh, but some see this as a first step towards gradually lifting the ban.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote Alain Delon
summary: As Alain Delon's health has recently declined, his three children have begun to fight over his inheritance. Here is how Le Monde covered the star actor over the years.

title: In the UK, Greater Manchester Police under fire after blatant negligence towards victims of a pedophile ring
summary: According to a report published on January 15, police and local authorities in the English city of Rochdale have for years ignored reports and testimonies from vulnerable minors who were victims of rape and sexual exploitation.

title: Yair Golan, the October 7 hero defying Benjamin Netanyahu
summary: Long branded a traitor by the Israeli right for criticizing government policies, the former IDF number two is now being celebrated across the country for his bravery during the Hamas attack. With the launch of the Hitorerut movement, this left-wing Zionist intends to turn his new-found popularity into voting intentions.

title: Japanese Moon lander  has 'resumed operations'
summary: Russia, China and other countries from South Korea to the United Arab Emirates are also trying their luck to reach the Moon.

title: Could cat-man be the new masculine ideal?
summary: On social media, men pose with their felines to prove that they are not predators. Some see it as the emergence of a masculine identity built around caring and attention.

title: Europe's Green Deal is attacked on all sides
summary: As the European Commission prepares a new 2040 CO₂ emissions reduction target, its Green Deal is undergoing a major test: Farmers, industrialists, public opinion and even governments are questioning it and calling for a 'regulatory pause.'

title: 'By treating immigration as a non-issue, the left relegates itself to the sidelines of formidable battles'
summary: The political fallout surrounding the French immigration law marks a stinging defeat for the left, whose inability to influence the debates is obvious, writes 'Le Monde' columnist Philippe Bernard.

title: China's real estate giant Evergrande ordered into liquidation by Hong Kong court
summary: The developer had accumulated debts to the order of $328 billion. It is not immediately clear how a legal decision taken in Hong Kong will play out in mainland China, where the group is based.

title: French farmers' protests: Faced with a 'week of danger,' PM Attal promises new measures
summary: On Sunday, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal pledged to 'move forward' on certain demands made by farmers, two days after presenting a first set of announcements in an attempt to quell the mobilization.

title: Brazil: Illegal gold panners have returned to Yanomami Indigenous territory
summary: A year ago, President Lula promised to put an end to illegal gold mining, which was damaging the health of the local population. But after evictions in early 2023, mining activity has resumed, owing to a lack of continuity in public action.

title: Why French farmers are continuing to protest
summary: The agricultural unions are planning a 'blockade' of Paris from Monday. Pesticides, free trade agreements, and wages are at the heart of their grievances.

title: Gaza: UN agency for Palestinian refugees plunged into unprecedented turmoil
summary: Israel said that a dozen UNRWA employees were involved in Hamas's October 7 attacks on Israel. The US and several Western countries suspended their funding for the agency.

title: UK reveals plan to ban disposable e-cigarettes
summary: Health experts welcomed Rishi Sunak's proposal, saying the legislation would have 'a major public health impact across many future generations.'

title: Italian PM Meloni set to unveil ambitious plans for Africa
summary: Giorgia Meloni is hosting African leaders in Rome for an Italy-Africa summit.

title: French farmers' protests: Map of Monday's roadblocks around Paris
summary: Two farmers' unions said they would set up eight roadblocks around the capital starting at 2 pm on Monday.

title: Gaza: UNWRA has questions to answer, but is indispensable
summary: Israel has accused employees of UNRWA of participating in the attack of October 7, 2023, but the alleged actions of a few must not be exploited at the expense of the many facing a humanitarian catastrophe.

title: Paris's Centre Pompidou: Employees' three-month strike ends
summary: Two labor unions signed an agreement on Monday to end the dispute at the modern art museum, which is set to close for renovation between 2025 and 2030.

title: Tennis: Paris Masters to relocate from Bercy to La Defénse Arena in 2025
summary: The French tennis federation said the move was taking place to comply with ATP requirements. The new venue can seat up to 23,000 spectators.

title: As French farmers protest, police instructed not to intervene at blockades
summary: France's interior minister has issued instructions to the police to exercise restraint. Fifteen thousand officers were mobilized to deal with the 'blockade' of Paris.

title: Recolonizing Gaza, the messianic vision of part of Israel's government
summary: Eleven ministers from Benjamin Netanyahu's government took part in a rally gathering several thousand people on Sunday, in which they advocated for the 'transfer' of Palestinians out of the Gaza Strip.

title: 'What has happened is genocide': Massacres in the Sudanese city of El Geneina
summary: According to a UN report, between 10,000 and 15,000 people – mainly from the Masalit community – were killed by General Hemedti's paramilitaries in the West Darfur city.
